questions.question_text: Which of the following helps ensure that a piece of evidence extracted from a PC is admissible in a court of law?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D. Chain of custody.

A chain of custody is a detailed, documented record of the sequence of custody, control, transfer, analysis, and disposition of evidence. It ensures that the evidence has not been tampered with, contaminated, or substituted. This is crucial for the admissibility of evidence in a court of law.

GG
It is D. Professor Messer mention this a couple of times.

Selected Answer: A
The correct answer is A. Static entry.

Explanation:

APIPA (Automatic Private IP Addressing): This is the correct identification of the IP address range 169.254.0.0/16. It indicates that the device has self-assigned an IP address because it couldn't obtain one from a DHCP server.
Static IP Address: To restore communication, the technician should assign a static IP address to the new machine. This involves manually configuring the IP address, subnet mask, default gateway, and DNS server addresses.

GG

Selected Answer: A
it does not have a DHCP server. so only way to restore communication with rest of the network is assign static entry. we know 169.254.x.x is a APIPA address but in the question , they didn't ask about this ip address. they asked , what action has to be taken to communicate with entire network.

A. Static Entry, you need to manually set the ip address. 
why its not C. apipa address would not fix the communication
C all day

questions.question_text: A network technician is deploying a new machine in a small branch office that does not have a DHCP server. The new machine automatically receives the IP address of 169.254.0.2 and is unable to communicate with the rest of the network. Which of the following would restore communication?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Select Start > Settings > Update & Security > Backup > Add a drive, and then choose an external drive.

questions.question_text: A user wants to back up a Windows 10 device. Which of the following should the user select?

discussion.content:
B. Load the system in safe mode.

Starting the system in safe mode allows the technician to boot into a minimal environment with only essential drivers and services running. This helps diagnose whether the issue is caused by a problematic driver or software conflict. If the system starts up successfully in safe mode, the technician can then proceed to troubleshoot further by identifying and resolving the specific cause of the freeze.

questions.question_text: A technician is unable to completely start up a system. The OS freezes when the desktop background appears, and the issue persists when the system is restarted. Which of the following should the technician do next to troubleshoot the issue?

choices.D: Enable Secure Boot and reinstall the system.
choices.C: Start up using a flash drive OS and run System Repair.
choices.B: Load the system in safe mode.

choices.C: Require a PIN on the unlock screen.

questions.question_text: A user's mobile phone has become sluggish. A systems administrator discovered several malicious applications on the device and reset the phone. The administrator installed MDM software. Which of the following should the administrator do to help secure the device against this threat in the future? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AE
I would go with A & E. I don't see how GPS spoofing will prevent this

Selected Answer: AE
Block the 3rd party apps.

Selected Answer: AE
One of the answers say root. Rootkit has to do with the hacking of an administrator I think, and rootkit is a malware. E just also sounded good to me.

Selected Answer: AE
A. Prevent a device root: Rooted devices are more vulnerable to malicious applications and potential security threats. By preventing the device from being rooted, the administrator can enhance security and prevent unauthorized access to system resources.

E. Block third-party application installation: Third-party applications pose a significant risk, as they may contain malware or other security vulnerabilities. By blocking third-party application installation, the administrator can ensure that only trusted and vetted applications from official app stores are installed on the device, reducing the risk of malicious software.

Options B, C, D, and F are not directly related to securing the device against the described threat

Selected Answer: AE
Blocking the way to go

There is one problem with A, the question did not mention whether is an IOS system device or an Android system device. Device root is a term that only works for Android but the question never mentions it. So C E would be a better choice for this question.

Selected Answer: AE
A and E. Read the question. The main concern is 3rd party apps and malware that have already been found on the phone. So it's evident that the user is adding 3rd party apps. Again, adding a pin that the user knows and giving him access to install 3rd party apps will on replicate the problem.

Selected Answer: AE
A. Prevent a device root.
E. Block third-party application installation.

Selected Answer: AE
Root detection is a security feature to identify whether the restrictions imposed by manufacturers of Android devices have been bypassed and block the 3rf party apps

Selected Answer: AE
I don't see how GPS spoofing will prevent this
Phone uses MDM that means that is company phone probably so A and C

Selected Answer: AE
GPS spoofing has nothing to do with the issue after the device was reset.
zot fou zot. Ena sois pagla, sois latet perdi. Merci

comments.content: No it is not. Requiring a PIN does not prevent the user from downloading malicious applications from third party sources, and most certainly would not stop a threat from accessing the device. 3rd party applications not approved and reviewed by the google play store is one of the main components in malicious software gaining access to a device.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AC
A. Prevent a device root and C. Require a PIN on the unlock screen would be the best steps the administrator can take to help secure the device against this threat in the future. Preventing a device root can help prevent unauthorized changes to the device's operating system or file system, which can be used to install malicious applications. Requiring a PIN on the unlock screen can help prevent unauthorized access to the device if it is lost or stolen. Disabling biometric authentication, enabling developer mode, and preventing GPS spoofing may not necessarily address the specific threat of malicious applications. Blocking third-party application installation may also be an option, but it may not be practical for some users who need to install legitimate third-party applications.
Can someone please tell me what Device Root is in their own words?

comments.content:
and allows the user to install 3rd party apps. It makes it more susceptible to exploits.

In Iphones i believe it's called jailbreaking. and I remember one practice test say that attackers try to find jailbroken phones.
Basically just admin mode on phone.

This is wrong. A is correct but E is the second correct answer. The question is asking about how to prevent the issue of malicious software being added to the device, not about physical unrestricted access to the device. A pin wouldn’t stop malware from coming onto a device if it’s ran by the user.

discussion.content:
The two actions the administrator should take to help secure the device against this threat in the future are:

A. Prevent a device root: Rooting a device can bypass the security measures put in place by the manufacturer or MDM software, making the device vulnerable to attacks.

C. Require a PIN on the unlock screen: This can help prevent unauthorized access to the device in case it gets lost or stolen.

Therefore, options A and C are the correct answers.

Disabling biometric authentication (option B) can make the device less secure as biometric authentication is often more secure than a PIN or password. Enabling developer mode (option D) can also make the device more vulnerable as it can allow unrestricted access to the device's software and settings. Preventing GPS spoofing (option F) is not directly related to securing the device against malicious applications. Option E, blocking third-party application installation, is also a good security measure, but it's not mentioned that the malicious applications were installed from third-party sources.

Selected Answer: AE
sure this

comments.content: You can't install thirparty application because they disable developer settings and you can't turn it on.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AE
As a previous Mobile Technician, most of the MDM device I work on you can't install third party application, and also can't flash anything on it answer is a and e

comments.content:
Blocking third-party application installation (option E) can be a helpful security measure, but requiring a PIN or other form of secure unlock method (option C) is generally a more effective way to protect the device against unauthorized access.

Even if third-party application installation is blocked, a PIN or other secure unlock method can help prevent an unauthorized user from accessing the device and potentially installing malicious applications from within the app store. A secure unlock method can also help protect the user's personal data in case the device is lost or stolen.

Furthermore, requiring a PIN or other secure unlock method is a built-in feature of most mobile devices and can be easily configured by the user or administrator, while blocking third-party application installation may require additional setup or third-party software.

I thought the same about the screen lock at first but then I thought about it and putting a screen lock on the phone only stops somebody from physically downloading any malicious apps. It doesn't say anything about that, it just states how they need to prevent the user from downloading any malicious apps.

Requiring a PIN will most certainly not help even a little bit in preventing malicious software from being installed on a users device. A PIN only helps with physical access to the device. As far as your reasoning as why E is wrong, it makes no sense at all. The whole reason the user got malware on their device was because of malicious software that was downloaded from a third party. Apps through the google play store are safe and approved by google. The issue would’ve never occurred if the user didn’t download third party apps. Therefore, A and E are the correct answers.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AC
A - This is obvious
C. Require a PIN on the unlock screen: Requiring a PIN or other form of secure unlock method can help prevent unauthorized access to the device and protect the user's personal data from being compromised.

E. Blocking third-party app installation can help prevent users from installing apps that are not vetted by the app store, but this alone may not be sufficient to prevent all malicious apps from being installed.

I go A,C
